title: Macquarie directors who took up full share entitlements ... twice
text:
On the topic of Macquarie Group directors: given the opportunity to participate in the company's recent Share Purchase Plan, two took up their full entitlements to discounted shares ... several times.

Veteran corporate director Jillian Broadbent added 250 shares (costing $30,000 in total) to her tally across two corporate vehicles, while ex-Westpac deputy CEO Philip Coffey splashed out $60,000 for 500 shares, split across four companies.

The SPP rules state that where individual eligible shareholders receive more than one offer to participate "because they hold shares in more than one capacity or in different registered holdings", their aggregate participation in the capital-raise shouldn't be more than $15,000 (or 125 shares that on Monday would be worth $16,438.75).

But the aforementioned directors aren't in breach of this clause because they provided Macquarie with custodian certificates to show their added exposure was only indirect.

Mind you, that doesn't mean they didn't get any extra benefit from participating more than once.

As well as taking up $15,000 worth of shares directly, Coffey's 3Y notes him as a beneficiary of Coffey Family Super, which took up its full entitlements. He's a director but not listed as a beneficiary of two other entities that added 125 shares each.

As for Broadbent, she took up $15,000 worth of shares in her own name, and another $15,000 through a company called Queens Park. Of which, her 3Y notice states, she is both a beneficiary and a trustee.

A Macquarie spokesperson said the bank was "comfortable that both the disclosures and the allocations are correct and in accordance with section 4.6 of the SPP terms".
description: Macquarie directors Jillian Broadbent and Philip Coffee benefited twice from its recent capital-raise.
